2.33 p.m.

    The Chairman: We are on the Main Estimates, 1964. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head as it appears in the last column of the abstract of estimated expenditure on pages 37 and 38 of Paper Cmd. 30 of 1963. Column: 389



2.34 p.m.

    Head 3-

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 3 be reduced by $100.

    Mr Speaker, I would like to know how public funds are being used in the Legislative Assembly. I would like to know whether Government documents used in the Legislative Assembly could also be printed in all the four official languages. The Prime Minister has said that he intends to appoint a Puisne Judge to be the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly. I would like to know the position on this matter.

Column: 390



    Another point is this. I hope there will be more supplies of different kinds of books for our reference in the Assembly Library. This will help us to understand better the situation and all matters relating to the State and to the society in Singapore in general.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, the Member has raised several points. I do not think I need labour the House with a long harangue on lines diametrically opposite to those that have been delivered by Members in the Opposition, apart for the fact that if we had not made special arrangements for terms and conditions of merger, the Member for Jalan Kayu would not have been here today even in spite of the split vote in his constituency. Being unable to speak English or Malay, he would be out, disqualified, and unable to take part in this debate. First of all, whilst we do not expect him to thank us for our forbearance and the great care we have taken to see that people like him should not be penalised, at least we do not expect him to come here and cause unnecessary trouble by raising problems about equality of languages.

    Next, the question of the Speaker. The Government has announced its intention, and this is a matter which requires the consent of the Federal Government. Needless to say, if the consent has already been obtained, an appointment may well have been made. The problem is whether we can satisfy the Federal Government to come to some arrangement whereby one of the judicial officers can, at the same time, either be seconded or otherwise freed, do these duties. At the right time and when finality is reached, the House will be informed.

    The third point is the Library. I do not know whether the Member for Jalan Kayu believes that the Assembly Library is really meant for political tracts and dissertations. If he did, then I think really the place for it is the National Library. I am sure all the treatises and pamphlets which he wants to read, for instance, about infantile Left-wing adventurism and how generally not to

Column: 391

make Marx and Lenin look like fools in Singapore, can be obtained in the National Library. But the Assembly Library is normally concerned with records of proceedings of this Legislature and treatises on rules, procedures and Standing Orders of this House. I am not saying that there is no vast store of literature in the other languages. They all have: Chinese, Tamil and, not least, Malay. But whether there are any useful publications to help Members in the deliberations of this House is another matter. If the Member for Jalan Kayu can make out a case why he has been at a disadvantage because he cannot understand, for instance, Erskine May on parliamentary practice and procedure, we might seriously consider setting up a team of translators to translate such useful treatises on parliamentary procedures, if he really finds that there is a need for that, and that he is at a disadvantage because he does not understand the English language.

    Mr Koo Young (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, only two days ago the Prime Minister said in his speech that he welcomed opinions and criticisms from even his own Back-benchers and Members from the Opposition. But when we put forward suggestions such as this one, he does not take them seriously. I remember the Member for Jalan Kayu has pointed out that the P.A.P. always raise the question of the Communist bogey. If everything can be explained away on the pretext of the Communist bogey, then nothing can be resolved. If he can use this term to evade every question, why should it be necessary to have any debate in this House? I hope those Members of the P.A.P. who were in this House some time ago, and who are now still here, will help to persuade the P.A.P. leadership to implement truly the use of the four official languages, orally as well as written, in this Legislative Assembly. I hope the Prime Minister has not forgotten the promise he made some time in the past. What is wrong with making this suggestion to use the four official languages, orally as well as written, in

Column: 392

all the printed papers? I would like him to let us know whether there are any difficulties in implementing this suggestion. We cannot deny that the Legislative Assembly occupies quite an important position, dealing as it does with all matters of State and public affairs in Singapore. Therefore, it is necessary that the four official languages should be used in the Legislative Assembly. The Prime Minister, of course, will remember that there are Members in this House who do not understand English. If all the documents are in English, then those who cannot master the English language will, of course, find it difficult to take part in the business of this House. Our suggestion is to enable every Member to understand the matter under discussion and the business that is conducted in this House so as to help in conducting the Assembly proceedings smoothly. The Prime Minister thinks that those who do not understand will have only themselves to blame. We hope that the books in the Library will be in other languages as well as in English. The Assembly Librarian will be in a position to look for the relevant books. In addition to books in English, we also hope there will be books in Chinese, Malay and Tamil available in the Assembly Library.

2.45 p.m.

    As to what books to supply to the Library, this question can be thrashed out by the Librarian himself. Why should the Prime Minister talk about buying books on Marxism and Leninism? In fact, we have never asked for these books. Hence the Government are not sincere in wanting to solve this question. On the other hand, they want the Opposition Members to make suggestions as to how to improve the running of this Assembly --- [Interruption] The Member for Jalan Besar should not say that. We are not the librarians of this Assembly or keepers of the Library. We should trust the Librarian. He will be able to get all the relevant books --- [Interruption].

    The Chairman: Order.

Column: 393



    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): If the Member for Jalan Besar is interested in these books, of course, we are not opposed to the buying of books like The Adventures of Pinnochio.

    Talking about the appointment of the Speaker of this House, the answer given by the Prime Minister about appointing a Puisne Judge to be the Speaker is very vague. We have now elected a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker, and these persons are Members of the P.A.P. What we want to say is that we hope the Prime Minister will not forget that it has been two and a half months since the general election was held on the 21st of September. If the Prime Minister is serious about getting a Puisne Judge to be the Speaker, his appointment to be approved by the Central Parliament, how is that we still have to wait for the appointment of this Puisne Judge as our Speaker? Why should they elect a Deputy Speaker? I want to know whether it is because they are unable to find a Puisne Judge to be Speaker. Whether it is because of the P.A.P.'s arrogance that some of the Judges do not want to come here to be the Speaker of this House? Who insult the Judges? It is the P.A.P. who always insult other people. We agree that the P.A.P. should appoint a Judge to be the Speaker of this House ---

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee)(In Mandarin): When did we agree to this?

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): I do not know what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture is talking about. I have no need to reply to the questions put forward by the Back-benchers of the Party in power --- [Interruption].

    The Chairman: Order. Please allow the Member to proceed.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Secondly, yesterday the Minister for Culture was consistently going against the rules and Standing Orders of this House when he made his speech. Therefore, we have no doubt why some of the Judges do not want to be the Speaker of this

Column: 394

House. It is because of the arrogant attitude of the P.A.P. --- [Interruption]. It is a fact. As Opposition Members, sometimes we feel sorry for the Speaker when he is in a very difficult position ---

    The Minister for Labour (Mr Jek Yeun Thong) (In Mandarin): The Member for Jalan Kayu has moved this amendment. Just because he does not understand the documents which are printed in English, he cannot blame the Assembly or the Budget, because in the past four years, especially when he was a member of the P.A.P., there was a provision in the Budget to enable Members to learn Malay and English and other languages. You are lazy. You do not want to make an effort to learn English or Malay ---

    Mr Poh Ber Liak (Tampines)(In Mandarin): I doubt whether now is the time to debate the proceedings in this House or to debate the question of our Assembly Members. It seems that the Minister is debating the Member for Jalan Kayu. I do not know what subject we should be discussing ---

    The Chairman: Order. Just allow the Minister to speak on a point of order.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong(In Mandarin): He himself has been unable to master either English or Malay or any of the four official languages. He has always allowed himself to be led by the nose by others. Now, what more does he want to complain? He now complains that there are not enough books for him to serve as references. He also complains that he cannot understand the books in English. Even if we give you books and documents in Chinese, you may not be able to understand too. Even if we translate all the documents and even the Budget into Chinese, you will not understand it, you will not be able to comprehend it. What is the use?

    We should thank the institution of this Legislative Assembly, because the Government is providing $500 allowance per month to enable them to criticise and attack the Government. In how many countries can you find these things in

Column: 395

practice? Not to talk about freedom of speech. If you dare to attack the Government or any leaders of the Government in certain countries, you will land in gaol or be banished or even disappear. Now in this House Assemblymen have various kinds of privileges. They are not liable to court action for their speeches made in this House and are not restricted under normal laws. Now, this is the spirit of parliamentary democracy.

    These few days we have to put away all our work to come to this House to listen to their speeches. Whatever they talked was like a stereotype gramophone record played over and over again, like an old grandmother's tale - long and stinking.

    The Opposition Members are even boasting about the length of their speeches, requesting us to compete with them in the length of speeches. That is not the purpose of this House. Neither is it the principle of legislative proceedings. They want to have all documents, the Budget and Bills to be translated into the three remaining official languages. At the moment, they have the right and the opportunity to make their speeches in Mandarin. But do they know how much money will have to be spent in translating all these documents and papers into all the three other official languages? This sum could very well have been used for other useful purposes, such as building roads and providing social amenities and facilities. Even if we provide documents and papers in Chinese, the Member for Jalan Kayu may not be able to understand them. He has raised the question of books in the Library. I remember that in the last session, there were certain publications in the Library called Monitoring Digest containing printed records of radio broadcasts from other countries. Now this is for the use of certain people who have need to study them. These Monitoring Digests are not for publication, and in the organ of the Barisan Sosialis they print certain quotations from these Digests, not from material supplied by the Voice of America, but from North Kalimantan

Column: 396

Radio, material advocating the destruction of Malaysia and making anti-Malaysia speeches.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, it pains me to find that the Minister for Labour whose skin is not white - but our Prime Minister's is somewhat red ---

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: On a point of order, Sir, I wonder whether the fact that my skin is white or yellow has got anything to do with ---

    The Chairman: What is the point of order?

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: The point of order is that the Member is making remarks irrelevant to what we are discussing.

    The Chairman: The Minister for Labour has also made personal remarks about the Member. He said the Member for Jalan Kayu could not read.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): If your skin is white, perhaps you could justify yourself to your forefathers and speak in English in this House, and you will be justified in criticising others for being unable to speak English.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Point of order, Sir, I do not remember making any reference to my ancestors.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): My suggestion for the amendment is made for the cause of equality of the four official languages in this House. This Assembly is the highest law-making body and should be the right place for implementing respect for all the four languages. It is the duty of the Assembly to implement it, because Singapore society is composed of various races. Since this House is an important body in the State, we should use all the four languages.

    The Minister for Labour has just now mentioned the extra expenditure incurred in translating these documents. But in the Ministry of Culture there is plenty of literature which nobody wants to read and which is a waste of public funds. Can

Column: 397

they justify their expenditure on publications of the Ministry of Culture?

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are now debating the proposed cut in the Legislative Assembly vote. But I am afraid the Member for Jalan Kayu is talking about the Ministry of Culture, and the waste of money on the publications of the Ministry of Culture.

    The Chairman: The Member is trying to make his point. Please proceed.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Fortunately the Speaker has some experience in guiding the proceedings of this House, otherwise what is to become of this House? There will be disrespect in this House.

    We should have reference books which might have come from other countries. The Prime Minister has been touring various countries in the world and has therefore acquired some knowledge and knows more from his experience. In the same way, we should also be given the opportunity to acquire more knowledge and know more things through literature in various languages. This is good for all and this suggestion is reasonable. I would urge the Government not to evade the question by saying that this is a political issue. I hope that the four official languages could be treated equally. This is not a political question.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj)(In Malay): I am surprised to see the behaviour of the Opposition Members today. They appear to be so keen on our expanding the Assembly Library. As Members of this Assembly, elected by the people, we should not depend on others to bring forward our arguments into this Assembly. The Government have established a National Library where books in all the four languages are available there. Members of the Assembly are provided with a special Library, and they, as well as members of the public, should go to the National Library for their books of reference.

Column: 398



    Mr R. A. Gonzales (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, I really do not know why the Opposition Members have asked for a reduction in Head 3 - Legislative Assembly - and, at the same time, ask for translations in the four languages. What they should have done is to ask the Minister for Finance to increase the amount allocated to the Legislative Assembly.

    For the last four days we have had dreary speeches about the unemployment position. The Opposition Members have said that there is unemployment all over Singapore. What they should have done is to ask the Government to increase the number of typists and translators probably in the Legislative Assembly in order that they can have translations, and therefore create employment.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I feel that equal treatment of the four languages is exposed as a falsehood in this Assembly. We see that the P.A.P. is only paying lip service to the policy of equal treatment of the four languages. Even in this House this equal treatment cannot be put to work. The P.A.P. is playing about with this question of giving equal treatment. We are not asking for something that cannot be done. It is not fair to have everything only in the English language. If we are really sincere in giving equal treatment to the four languages, then it should first be done in this House.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I think I had better bring the debate back to the rails. Perhaps I will give them the best construction possible on their motives. The best construction is, I think, a genuine misunderstanding on their part. The Assembly Library is not an ordinary library meant for general reading. The purpose of the Library is to have treatises on parliamentary procedure and practice as in Britain and other parts of the British Commonwealth which have adopted this parliamentary practice. There are, therefore, no Chinese books written on this anywhere in the world, nor for that matter Malay hooks or Tamil books.

Column: 399

Therefore, if Members of the Opposition feel that they find any particular kind of text-book of assistance, i will seriously consider the proposition that translations should be made. [Interruption] One at a time.

    Mr Speaker, I intend to meet all the points that have been raised. As for the Library, as I have said, if the Barisan really want any other reading material, then the proper place is not the Assembly Library but the National Library. When we come to the Ministry of Culture estimates, that is the time to point out whether or not the Ministry of Culture is doing its duty in providing reading material and literature in the Chinese language - indeed in any other language, Tamil and Malay.

    So I really ask them to consider whether, in fact, they want to pursue this matter. If they really want to, then I say I am quite prepared. The leading textbook on Constitutional and Parliamentary Practice is Erskine May's, a book of over 1,000 pages, full of technicalities. If necessary, I will even consider a commission to translate it if it is of any value to Members opposite. Other than that, we get donated to us proceedings of other Parliaments in the British Commonwealth; free of charge, they give them to us and we put them in the Library.

    Sir, I think the point of substance is - I agree this is a point of substance - about notice papers, and so on. Members will notice that at the ceremonial opening of the Assembly the Order Paper for that day was printed in four languages. If the staff of this Assembly plus the staff of the Government Printing Office can cope with the work, we will likewise do every single Order Paper. I concede that. What I would like to point out is that we have inherited a Government Printing Office which only prints in English. The Ministry of Culture is at the present moment trying to build up a section that can print in Malay, Tamil and Chinese. When that section is built up, and provided we can at the same time build up a coterie of translators, we will let all Members

Column: 400

have all notifications in all four languages. [Interruption] Do they want it? Surely I am assuming that they do not want us to do it only in Chinese. If we do it, then we have got to do it also in Malay and Tamil. [Interruption] That is a matter ---

3.15 p.m.

    Inche Mahmud Awang (Kampong Kapor)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, it seems that you remain silent when the Opposition Members interrupt the Prime Minister.

    The Chairman: Perhaps it is because the Prime Minister was speaking English.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the plain fact of the matter is this. This was decided by an All-Party Commission back in 1957 and the Members opposite besides the Member for Jalan Kayu may not be aware of this. But it was found that it is impossible with the administration at present constituted with both the clerical staff - the Government Printing side - and interpreters at our disposal to have simultaneous records of all documents distributed to Members in four languages. And therefore, for convenience sake, they retain the use of English.

    Sir, I will be quite frank and say that it will never be possible at any time to run all four records in all four languages. It is something which not even the United Nations can successfully do. But I do promise the Members opposite that whilst we will always maintain the liberty of each Member to use his own language, the moment there are sufficient men and material and the printing capacity to do it, the records will be kept in the national language. And I do urge the Member for Jalan Kayu to utilise the opportunity we offered him in the last Assembly and in this Assembly to really make an effort, otherwise if in five years' time we have built up this whole apparatus, he may find himself illiterate.

    Now, Sir, about the Speaker. But before I go to that, I would like to make this point. I think Members on the opposite side run a very grave risk of playing this dangerous line of saying

Column: 401

that we are not equal. Sir, I am prepared to meet this problem all the time and every time. But I say that they have already been well isolated from the mass of the public, playing all kinds of dangerous external lines. The foreign policy of the P.K.I. is the internal policy of the Barisan. Now they play on language and sentiments. It is our job to see that these very sensitive and highly-charged issues are played down. And I say, if they have a genuine point to make, I will meet it genuinely. But generally to say that we are not treating the Chinese language - and really they are only interested in the Chinese language; let us be quite frank about that - equally with the others, I say that it is not only an untruth but a positively dangerous line to pursue. If they have a genuine complaint and if they do not really understand what is being said in the notices, I will consider during Assembly sittings to try to get some translators seconded from the Courts to try and help them. But this is not a genuine misunderstanding or incapacity to comprehend. This is deliberate mischief making, and I say they do so at their peril. This is a country with a plural society. If we play one without taking into account the sensitivities of the others, there will be real trouble. So I urge them not to pursue this line. Our policy of equal treatment for the four streams was decided by an All-Party Commission, that it is only feasible to have one administrative language. Wherever possible - at ceremonial openings, and so on - we put it in all languages. If really there is a need, they do not understand it, I am prepared during Assembly sittings, as I have said, to bring in interpreters. But to play this as a propaganda line is a very dangerous line. I will meet it. I say we will survive. But I am not so sure whether the country can stand these stresses and strains. One thing is definite. If the next wretched riot takes place, like the Bertha Hertogh riot, we will not have enough policemen to guard the Member for Jalan Kayu and all the Members opposite.

Column: 402



    Sir, the question of the Speaker. I had hoped that Members opposite would have shown a certain amount of decorum and good taste. They say they welcome our desire to appoint a High Court Judge concurrently as Speaker of this Assembly. They have cast aspersions that perhaps no High Court Judge wishes to be a Speaker. I think, Mr Speaker, Sir, you are in an invidious position in that you lean over backwards to be more than fair to them, because there can he no allegation about that. And I see the advantage of having an impartial non-party Speaker who is doing a completely impartial duty, like a Judge, to take this office. I have explained publicly the reason for the need to get the consent of the Central Government, because the Judiciary is now in the Federal vote. I do not want to go into the details. I have been pressed now. All right, I will say this now. The Central Government having taken the advice of not our Judiciary - our Judiciary is quite happy with this arrangement and is quite prepared to allow one of the Judges concurrently to act as Speaker - but the Federal side of the Judiciary feel that they should not duplicate their functions. I am now putting forward a proposition to the Central Government that perhaps one Judge could be seconded to fulfil this function for the term of this Assembly, and if the next Assembly does not wish to have him continue, then he can go back and be a Judge. This matter requires a certain amount of deliberation and consideration. But I think one thing is quite clear, Mr Speaker, Sir. What the Members on the opposite side understand is the kind of fight they carry out where they kick a man when he is down and if they had won ---

    The Chairman: Order. Time has elapsed. Will the Member for Jalan Kayu indicate whether he wishes to withdraw the amendment?

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to withdraw my amendment. But ---

    The Prime Minister: On a point of order. My point of order is that when a Member withdraws, he withdraws. He does not make another

Column: 403

speech. I beg your pardon, Mr Speaker, Sir. One of the problems which I wanted to anticipate was to have a Speaker who also understands the language of the Opposition in order that they can be checkmate before they are out of order through the interpretation.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $701,300 for Head 3 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 403



    Head 6 -

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 6 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (3) of subhead 1.

    I know that when we raise many questions the P.A.P. Members always harp on the need to economise. I do not understand why the Government are prepared to spend $1,350 per month on the post of Personal Secretary (Political). We know that the present incumbent of this post is the defeated candidate for Bukit Panjang. [Interruption in Mandarin] Dr Lee Siew Choh did not ask you to appoint him as a Political Secretary. Why should the Government spend $1,350 on a person who was defeated in the last election? It looks as if this post is a kind of refuge for a defeated candidate of the P.A.P. The Minister for Finance realises that we are facing financial difficulties. Since that is so, we need to be economical. [Interruption in Mandarin] It is a waste of public money to provide for this post. What have these Political Secretaries done or, for that matter, what can they do for the people? There are many people who are out of job and these people are increasing in number. The salary paid to a Political Secretary amounting to $1,350 a month is quite enough to feed one family for one year. [Interruption in Mandarin] Mr Speaker, Sir, the Members of this House - whether Government or Opposition Members - have been elected by the people and the $500 a month paid to each Member is not from the purse of the Minister for Labour. [Interruption in Mandarin] Mr Wong Soon Fong and Mr Chan Sun Wing never [Interruption in Mandarin] ---

Column: 404



    The Chairman: The hon. Member should proceed. When the Government side get the same treatment from the Opposition, they will not like it. I think we should allow him to proceed.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir [Interruption in Mandarin] - there is a saying that if one has not made a careful examination, one should not have the right to speak. If the Members opposite do not know the real situation and facts and talk at random, then they will be doing wrong to themselves. [Interruption in Mandarin]

    The Chairman: May I remind the Members of the Government not to interrupt?

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, whenever Members of the Opposition speak, we are always faced with two reactions: one is interference and the other is that whenever the Government are unable to rebut or argue, they always raise the Communist bogey. [Interruption in Mandarin] How many questions have we raised which they have never been able to answer?

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, since our first Budget was put forward at the end of 1959, the men who opposed the posts of Political Secretaries were Members of the S.P.A. But today the opposition that was voiced by the S.P.A. is now voiced by the Barisan Sosialis. When the strong men in the Barisan Sosialis - Mr Lim Ching Siong, Mr Fong Swee Suan and Mr Woodhull - held the posts of Political Secretaries, they did not object to these posts. But now they say that it is a waste of money. These Political Secretaries are important to the Ministers and to the people of Singapore. If they are loyal to Malaysia, then they are good. So I am surprised that the question of the Political Secretaries which was raised by the S.P.A. led by Tun Lim Yew Hock is now raised and debated at length by the Barisan Sosialis.

3.30 p.m.
